chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Today we will talk about environment variables.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: How can you use environment variables in Next.js

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: We will talk about some important details related to environment variables.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: You just like the video and write Next.js op in the comment section.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Let's go to the computer screen.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Let's roll the intro.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Alright, so I will quickly make a Next.js app here.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: I will name it environment variables.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: And it has started to create.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: I will continue with my default options.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: And you can see that this app is created.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So I will go to the environment variables folder and open with code.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: And I can run my app by typing npm run dev.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: npm run dev

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: And you see my app will start here.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: No surprises whatsoever.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So you see here our app has started.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Now let's talk about environment variables.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: What are environment variables?

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: If I make a file here with the name .env

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: And I write here let us say secret

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: secret

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: secret is equal to

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: and I write here harry123456

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: And let's say this is our email id.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: I write here id

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: is equal to harry

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So I have stored some credentials here.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Now why didn't we hard code it directly in the app?

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Why are we storing it separately here?

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: The reason is that these credentials can be changed.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Or they can be configurable variables.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Or they can be so secret that

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: I will push my code on github.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So I don't want to push these credentials on github.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: For example, when we make AI projects,

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: then the key of openai is used in it.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So I don't want my openai key to be pushed here.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So we separate things.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: There are two reasons.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: One is that we want to change it again and again.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Where will we keep looking in the code?

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Where is the key? Where is the secret?

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Where will we keep finding and replacing?

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: We have written it here and we can use it in our code.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: Now let me show you how to use this id and secret.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So if I want to use id and secret,

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: then I can do console.log here.

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So is there no way to put

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4

chunks.text: Suppose I want the id

chunks.text: You have to do next

chunks.title: Environment Variables in Next.js  Sigma Web Development Course - Tutorial #134.mp4
chunks.text: So by doing this it will become a public environment variable

text: Today we will talk about environment variables. How can you use environment variables in Next.js We will talk about some important details related to environment variables. You just like the video and write Next.js op in the comment section. Let's go to the computer screen. Let's roll the intro. Alright, so I will quickly make a Next.js app here. I will name it environment variables. And it has started to create. I will continue with my default options. And you can see that this app is created. So I will go to the environment variables folder and open with code. And I can run my app by typing npm run dev. npm run dev And you see my app will start here. No surprises whatsoever. So you see here our app has started. Now let's talk about environment variables. What are environment variables? If I make a file here with the name .env And I write here let us say secret secret secret is equal to and I write here harry123456 And let's say this is our email id. I write here id is equal to harry So I have stored some credentials here. Now why didn't we hard code it directly in the app? Why are we storing it separately here? The reason is that these credentials can be changed. Or they can be configurable variables. Or they can be so secret that I will push my code on github. So I don't want to push these credentials on github. For example, when we make AI projects, then the key of openai is used in it. So I don't want my openai key to be pushed here. So we separate things. There are two reasons. One is that we want to change it again and again. Where will we keep looking in the code? Where is the key? Where is the secret? Where will we keep finding and replacing? We have written it here and we can use it in our code. Now let me show you how to use this id and secret. So if I want to use id and secret, then I can do console.log here. Note that this is a server component. And I write it a little more simply. div hey this is home I write here I write in console.log key the id is and colon process.n. and here I will write id and you see as soon as it is compiled, the id is written here. So this page was refreshed and the id is written here. You have seen here id is written here. Can we do the same for secret? Yes, we can. So this is our conversation on the server. We printed the id on the server. We printed the secret on the server. If we have to send it anywhere, then we will send it. secret is secret is and it will be refreshed and see the id is here secret is here. Why is it being refreshed? Because this page keeps loading live. As you change it. So this is our development server. As soon as we change it, it takes the effect. Now we have seen that id and secret are printed. Let's do one thing. Why don't we show this id on the page here? I say hey this is home the id is I try to write it here. You will think that id will be here and secret will be here. If I write here and secret is and I print the secret like this. So what will happen? It should be printed. Here the id is harry and here the secret is harry. 1,2,3,4,5,6 will be printed. But let me show you something. What I will do now is I will make it a client component. I will say make it a client component. Now you have to remember one thing that when I made it a client component, I will comment this line. Because nothing is working on the server. Now I wrote here hey this is home the id is process.env.id and secret is process.env.secret Now when we were on the server then process.env was loaded and all the variables were loaded on the server. Because server is a component. Page is being made on the server. These variables are on the server. Now it is hydrated. But when we are on the client. When we wrote here use client and because we are on the client site so now process.env will be client.process.env and as a result the id is nothing and the secret is nothing. So what happened? Why it didn't come? We made it a client component so it didn't come. Everything was working fine. Because process.env is loaded on the server and not on the client. In Next.js the environment of server and client are different. So this process.env will be client.process.env i.e. browser.process.env in which it won't get. Neither id nor secret because it is on the server. So is there no way to put our id here and it will show here. Suppose I want the id to be visible on the browser. Do you know why it was done? So that your environment variables don't get exposed by mistake. All environment variables are not exposed. You have to do next underscore public underscore and as soon as you write next underscore public underscore id is equal to harry so now you can access it. And I will tell you why it happens. So you see here id is harry is written. When we write next underscore public underscore id, process.env dot, so next.js automatically starts the environment variables from next underscore public underscore and sends all those environment variables to the browser. Which means that even if I remove these use lines from here then my server site will work perfectly. And you saw on the client site it was working. So if you want that these environment variables become a part of your JavaScript bundle which goes to the client site if your client component is on the client site then through JavaScript bundle if you want to access process.env. this environment variable through the client and server then you can write next underscore public. So by doing this it will become a public environment variable which means it will be a part of JavaScript bundle. But note that don't do this for sensitive variables your database password No, don't make next underscore public because attackers will remove it from the JavaScript bundle if you think that I am not displaying it then it will become a part of JavaScript bundle and you will become vulnerable for the attack so I don't want you to be vulnerable for the attack. Now we talked about .env so the environment variables that was pretty much it but now let's talk a little more advanced. It's simple it's advanced but simple so if I make a file .env.local and I write here public id is equal to rohan and I write here rohan123456 or rohan3456 so I make it a server component and after making a server component you see that rohan and rohan3456 are printing so .env.local takes more priority if there is any variable in it then will it load? Yes so I will tell you how to load and why this file is made like this whenever you are making an app you are working on a production environment and you are working in a production environment where you push your code so in this way your local environment variables are different and your production environment variables are different for example if you are using mongodb so in production your mongodb credential is different your URI is different it is different in local so in local if you want to put something different in production then you make .env.local and it will load first so .env.local is added first and then .env is given priority if .env.local is not present then .env environment variables will load now we will go to nextjs documentation and we will see the priority that how it loads so I will search nextjs environment variables and here is a page of environment variables it has a lot of information including the next public information that we already talked about but what I want is that we read only those things which are important now see this line that what is the order of load in which order environment variables are loaded first of all your process.env will be loaded means operating system environment variables are not there so .env. suppose your development server is there so development.local, production is there so .env.local will be loaded and then .env .env.node which can be development or production and .env after that priority is given now here node.env values are production, development and test this is good to know at the same time let me tell you that you don't need to remember all these things I will be very honest with you you don't need to remember the reason is that mostly 95% of the time we are going to use .env.local and .env so you just need to know that .env.local is there so that will be prioritized and if it is not there then .env will be loaded suppose I make a name environment variable and I put name shubham and if I try to access the name and name is process.env. and here I will write the name so if I do this then shubham will come here and he loaded .env.local and this shubham he loaded it from .env because it was not present here so mostly you need to know this .env.local will be read first whatever is found is found, whatever is not found then it will be loaded from .env if it is present so that was about environment variables according to me you just need to know this there is a lot of advanced stuff but this was pretty much just of this page which I told you in this video, next underscore public is really very important you need to understand it well for the rest when we will make projects and on this channel you will get to see a lot of things which will be pretty much basics but how to deal, when to make .env.local, when to make .env environment variable you will get to know all this so I hope you like this video thank you for watching this video and I will see you
